qas.question: Along with the surface of the Earth, what objects absorb radiation from the sun?
After Earth surface's absorbs radiation, in what spectrum is much of it re-emitted?
Along with water vapor, what atmospheric substance primarily absorbs the infrared emitted by the Earth?
What notable warming effect does the presence of infrared absorbers contribute to?
What does the greenhouse effect absorb from the sun?
After Earth absorbs methane, in what spectrum is it re-emitted?
What substances absorb the sulfur hexafluoride emitted by the Earth?
What keeps the atmosphere and surface re-radiated?
What substances emit water vapor back to the atmosphere?

context: Earth's surface and the <a0_0>clouds<a0_0/> absorb <b4_0>visible and invisible radiation<b4_0/> from the sun and re-emit much of the energy as <a1_0>infrared<a1_0/> back to atmosphere. Certain substances in the atmosphere, chiefly <a2_0><b6_0>cloud droplets<a2_0/> and water vapor<b6_0/>, but also carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, sulfur hexafluoride, and chlorofluorocarbons, absorb this <b5_0>infrared<b5_0/>, and re-radiate it in all directions including back to Earth. Thus, the <a3_0><b7_0>greenhouse<a3_0/> effect<b7_0/> keeps the atmosphere and surface much warmer than if the <b8_0>infrared absorbers<b8_0/> were absent from the atmosphere.
